feature.name: Abellio
feature.origin: Gaul god of the apple tree.

feature.name: Achita
feature.origin: Nigerian god of agriculture.

feature.name: Ahuna Mons
feature.origin: Sumi tribe (Nagaland, NE India) traditional post-harvest festival, signifies the celebration of the seasons harvest’s thanksgiving.

feature.name: Annona
feature.origin: Roman goddess of crops and of the harvest.

feature.name: Anura
feature.origin: Arawakan (Guyana) spirit of the tobacco seeds.

feature.name: Aristaeus
feature.origin: Greek god of agriculture.

feature.name: Asari
feature.origin: Syrian god of agriculture.

feature.name: Attis
feature.origin: Greek/Phrygian god of vegetation and of fertility.

feature.name: Axomama
feature.origin: Incan goddess of potato, “Potato-mother.”

feature.name: Aymuray Tholi
feature.origin: Quechua (Peru) harvest festival (in May). Aymuray means “the song of the harvest”.

feature.name: Azacca
feature.origin: Haitian god of agriculture.

feature.name: Bagach Tholus
feature.origin: Belarusian harvest festival (21 September).

feature.name: Baltay Catena
feature.origin: Mordvinian (Volga River Region, Russia) agricultural festival.

feature.name: Begbalel
feature.origin: Yap Islands (Caroline Islands, Micronesia) guardian of the taro fields who controls the yield of the crops.

feature.name: Belun
feature.origin: Belarus god of the fields.

feature.name: Besua
feature.origin: Egyptian grain god.

feature.name: Bilwis
feature.origin: German corn spirit.

feature.name: Binayo
feature.origin: Philippine (Hanunoo/Mangyan, Mindoro Island) female spirit, caretaker of the rice spirits.

feature.name: Bonsu
feature.origin: Bateg/Batek (Malaysia) god who watches over the fruits and flowers.

feature.name: Braciaca
feature.origin: Celtic god of malt.

feature.name: Cacaguat
feature.origin: Nicaraguan god of cacao.

feature.name: Cachimana
feature.origin: Atabapo and Inirida tribes’ (Upper Orinoco River region, Venezuela) vegetation god who ripens the crops and controls the seasons.

feature.name: Centeotl
feature.origin: Mexican god/goddess of maize and agriculture.

feature.name: Cerealia Facula
feature.origin: The major festival in Ancient Rome to celebrate for the grain goddess Ceres (8 days in mid- to late April).

feature.name: Cerealia Tholus
feature.origin: The major festival in Ancient Rome to celebrate for the grain goddess Ceres (8 days in mid- to late April).

feature.name: Chaminuka
feature.origin: Shona (Zimbabwe) spirit who provides rains in times of droughts.

feature.name: Coniraya
feature.origin: Inca god who was responsible for the system of agricultural terracing and irrigation.

feature.name: Consus
feature.origin: Italian agricultural god who watched over the harvested and stored crop.

feature.name: Cosecha Tholus
feature.origin: Colombian harvest festival, Fiestas de La Cosecha, held in August at Pereira. (Cosecha means ‘harvest’ in Spanish).

feature.name: Cozobi
feature.origin: Zapotec (S. Mexico) god of maize and of abundant food.

feature.name: Dada
feature.origin: Nigerian god of vegetables.

feature.name: Dalien Tholus
feature.origin: Bon Dalien; Khmer (Cambodia) festival at the end of the rice harvest (January – February).

feature.name: Damia
feature.origin: Greek goddess of the cornfield and of crops.

feature.name: Dankdag Labes
feature.origin: Dutch (The Netherlands) day of thanksgiving for the crop (1st Wednesday of November).

feature.name: Dantu
feature.origin: Ghanan god associated with the planting of the corn.

feature.name: Darzamat
feature.origin: Darzamate, Dārza-māte; Latvian spirit, “Mother of the garden.”

feature.name: Datan
feature.origin: Polish god of the tilling of the soil.

feature.name: Dikhan
feature.origin: Dikhan baba; Kazakh preislamic deity of farming.

feature.name: Doliku
feature.origin: Dahomey (Benin) god of the fields.

feature.name: Duginavi
feature.origin: Kogi (N. Colombia) god, who taught people agriculture.

feature.name: Emesh
feature.origin: Sumerian god of vegetation, agriculture.

feature.name: Enkimdu
feature.origin: Sumerian god of farming.

feature.name: [Erntedank Planum]
feature.origin: Erntedanktag/Erntedankfest; Harvest thanksgiving festival in Germany, Austria and Switzerland (in September – October).

feature.name: Ernutet
feature.origin: Egyptian cobra-headed goddess of the harvest.

feature.name: Ezinu
feature.origin: Sumerian goddess of the grain.

feature.name: Fejokoo
feature.origin: Nigerian god who supplied the yams.

feature.name: Fluusa
feature.origin: Oscan (ancient S. Italy) goddess of flowers, counterpart of Roman goddess Flora.

feature.name: Gaue
feature.origin: Germanic goddess to whom offerings are made in harvesting the rye.

feature.name: Gerber Catena
feature.origin: Udmurt (Volga-Ural Region, Russia) agricultural festival after the spring sowing (June).

feature.name: Geshtin
feature.origin: Sumerian/Babylonian goddess of the vine.

feature.name: Ghanan
feature.origin: Mayan god of maize.

feature.name: Hakumyi
feature.origin: Paraguay, Brazil, and Bolivia spirit helpful in gardening.

feature.name: Halki
feature.origin: Hittite (Asia Minor) goddess of grain.

feature.name: Hamori
feature.origin: Japanese god, protector of tree leaves.

feature.name: Hanami Planum
feature.origin: Japanese cherry blossom festival.

feature.name: Hatipowa
feature.origin: Indian god of agriculture.

feature.name: Haulani
feature.origin: Hau-lani; Hawaiian plant goddess.

feature.name: Heneb
feature.origin: Egyptian god of grain, produce, and vineyards.

feature.name: Homshuk
feature.origin: Popoluca (S. Mexico) spirit of corn (maize).

feature.name: Hosil Tholus
feature.origin: Hosil bayrami; Uzbek (Central Asia) cotton harvest festival.

feature.name: Ialonus
feature.origin: British god of the cultivated field and of the meadows.

feature.name: Ikapati
feature.origin: Philippine goddess of the cultivated lands.

feature.name: Inamahari
feature.origin: Ancient Siouan (S. Carolina, USA) pair of male and female deities invoked for success at the sowing season.

feature.name: Inkosazana
feature.origin: Zulu (South Africa) agricultural goddess.

feature.name: Insitor
feature.origin: Roman agricultural deity in charge of the sowing.

feature.name: Jacheongbi
feature.origin: Korean Earth goddess who brought 5 grains to Jeju island, and began agriculture.

feature.name: Jaja
feature.origin: Abkhazian (Transcaucasia) harvest goddess.

feature.name: Jarimba
feature.origin: Arunta/Aranda (Australia) god of flowers and fruit.

feature.name: Jarovit
feature.origin: Slavic god of fertility and harvest, who comes down to the Underworld after every harvest and returns to a usual world every spring.

feature.name: Juling
feature.origin: Sakai/Orang Asli (Malaysia) spirit of the crops.

feature.name: Jumis
feature.origin: Latvian god of fertility of the field.

feature.name: Junina Catenae
feature.origin: Brazilian festival with a rural theme held in June at end of rainy season to give thanks for fertile rain.

feature.name: Kahukura
feature.origin: Maori (New Zealand) god of kumara (sweet potato) crops.

feature.name: Kaikara
feature.origin: Konjo and Banyoro/Nyoro (Uganda) goddess of harvest.

feature.name: Kait
feature.origin: Hattic goddess of grain (Asia Minor).

feature.name: Kaneki
feature.origin: Micronesian (Pohnpei/Ponape Island, Caroline Islands) god of the coconut palm.

feature.name: Kekri Tholus
feature.origin: Finnish harvest festival (first Saturday of November).

feature.name: Kerwan
feature.origin: Hopi spirit of the sprouting maize (Arizona, SW USA).

feature.name: Kiriamma
feature.origin: Veddan (Sri Lanka) goddess, provider of food (“Milk mother”).

feature.name: Kirnis
feature.origin: Lithuanian spirit, guardian of cherry trees.

feature.name: Kokopelli
feature.origin: Pueblo (SW USA) fertility deity, who presides over agriculture.

feature.name: Kondos
feature.origin: Finnish agricultural deity.

feature.name: Kumitoga
feature.origin: Polynesian goddess of plant life.

feature.name: Kupalo
feature.origin: Russian god of vegetation and of the harvest.

feature.name: Kwanzaa Tholus
feature.origin: African-American festival ("First Fruits") based on ancient African harvest festivals (from December 26 to January 1).

feature.name: Laukumate
feature.origin: Latvian spirit, “Mother of the fields.”

feature.name: Liber
feature.origin: Roman god of agriculture.

feature.name: Liberalia Mons
feature.origin: Ancient Roman festival to honor Liber and Libera, deities of the vine, worshiped, along with Ceres as fertility gods, held on March 17.

feature.name: Lociyo
feature.origin: Zapotec (Mexico) deity to whom a ceremony is performed when the first chili plant is cut.

feature.name: Lohri Tholus
feature.origin: Punjabi (Pakistan, NW India) harvest festival. Held on January 13.

feature.name: Lono
feature.origin: Hawaiian god of agriculture.

feature.name: Lughnasa Tholus
feature.origin: Celtic harvest festival, traditionally celebrated on August 1.

feature.name: Makahiki Labyrinthus
feature.origin: Hawaiian harvest festival in honor of Lono, a god of fertility, agriculture, and rainfall (lasts four months, from October through February).

feature.name: Meanderi
feature.origin: Ngaing (New Guinea) goddess of taro, sugar cane, and other foods.

feature.name: Megwomets
feature.origin: Yurok (California, USA) dwarf god of acorns and the distributor of vegetal abundance.

feature.name: Messor
feature.origin: Roman god of harvesting, of cutting of the grain.

feature.name: Mikeli Tholus
feature.origin: Mikeldiena; Latvian harvest festival. Held at the end of September.

feature.name: Mlezi
feature.origin: Name of god Tilo as “Food-Giver” (Tonga tribes of Malawi and Zambia).

feature.name: Mondamin
feature.origin: Ojibwe /Chippewa corn (maize) god (Lake Superior area, Canada and USA).

feature.name: Nabanna Fossa
feature.origin: Bengal region (Bangladesh and West Bengal state in India) “new rice” harvest festival.

feature.name: Nar Sulcus
feature.origin: Azerbaijani festival of pomegranate harvest. Held in October – November in Goychay city, center of pomegranates cultivation in Azerbaijan.

feature.name: Nawish
feature.origin: Acoma (New Mexico, SW USA) guardian of the field.

feature.name: Nepen
feature.origin: Egyptian god of rain.

feature.name: Niman Rupes
feature.origin: Hopi (SW USA) ritual ending the katsina (spiritual beings) season, celebrates the katsinas’ return to their spiritual home in July and their part in the blossoming of plant life.

feature.name: Ninsar
feature.origin: Sumerian goddess of plants and vegetation.

feature.name: Nunghui
feature.origin: Canelos Quichua (Ecuador) female spirit of the garden soil and of pottery clay.

feature.name: Occator
feature.origin: Roman agricultural deity of the harrowing.

feature.name: Oltagon
feature.origin: Philippine agricultural goddess.

feature.name: Omonga
feature.origin: Tomori/Mori (Celebes/Sulawesi, Indonesia) rice spirit who dwells in the Moon.

feature.name: Onam Labes
feature.origin: Harvest festival in Kerala, India, held in August-September.

feature.name: Oxo
feature.origin: God of agriculture in Afro-Brazilian beliefs of Yoruba derivation.

feature.name: Pasola Facula
feature.origin: Festival of rice planting season at Sumba Island (Lesser Sunda Islands, E. Indonesia). (February – March).

feature.name: Peko
feature.origin: Seto (SE Estonia) fertility god.

feature.name: Piuku
feature.origin: Barama River Caribs (Guyana) god of the manioc.

feature.name: Pongal Catena
feature.origin: Tamil (Sri Lanka and S. India) harvest festival observed in mid-January. It is a time for giving thanks to nature.

feature.name: Rao
feature.origin: Polynesian god of turmeric.

feature.name: Ratumaibulu
feature.origin: Fijian serpent god of agriculture and the underworld. He makes the breadfruit and other fruit trees blossom and yield fruit.

feature.name: Razeka
feature.origin: Arabian tribal god worshipped as the provider of food.

feature.name: Rongo
feature.origin: Maori (New Zealand) god of agriculture, of cultivated foods.

feature.name: Roskva
feature.origin: Teutonic goddess who symbolizes the ripe fields of harvest.

feature.name: Samhain Catenae
feature.origin: Gaelic festival at the end of the harvest season. It was observed in Ireland and Scotland during 7 days in October and November, nearly halfway between the autumn equinox and the winter solstice.

feature.name: Sedana
feature.origin: Indonesian (Bali and Java Islands) god of agriculture.

feature.name: Sekhet
feature.origin: Egyptian name of Isis as goddess of cultivated lands and fields.

feature.name: Shakaema
feature.origin: Jivaro (Ecuador and Peru) god of vegetation invoked in the planting and cultivation of bananas.

feature.name: Shennong
feature.origin: Shen Nong; Chinese buffalo-headed agricultural deity, who taught humans the use of the plow together with other aspects of basic agriculture.

feature.name: Sintana
feature.origin: Columbian deity who produced the fertile black earth for sowing.

feature.name: Sukkot Labes
feature.origin: Jewish autumn festival of double thanksgiving, celebrated for 8 days in September – October.

feature.name: Tafakula
feature.origin: Tongan (Polynesia) goddess invoked for favorable seasons for the crops.

feature.name: Tahu
feature.origin: Maori (New Zealand) personification of all food.

feature.name: Takel
feature.origin: Malaysian goddess in charge of the tuber harvest.

feature.name: Tawals
feature.origin: Polish god of the fields, of the tilling.

feature.name: Telepinu
feature.origin: Hittite (Asia Minor) god of fertility and vegetation.

feature.name: Thrud
feature.origin: Scandinavian goddess who “Signifies the seed.”

feature.name: Tibong
feature.origin: Land Dayaks (Borneo/Kalimantan, Indonesia) malevolent spirit who devours and depletes the rice.

feature.name: Toharu
feature.origin: Pawnee (Nebraska, Central USA) god of food and vegetation.

feature.name: Tupo
feature.origin: Polynesian god of turmeric.

feature.name: Uhola Catenae
feature.origin: Nigerian (Zuru Emirate, Kebbi State) harvest festival.

feature.name: Urvara
feature.origin: Indian and Iranian deity of plants and fields.

feature.name: Vendimia Planitia
feature.origin: Grape harvest festival in Mendoza (Argentina) during the first week of March. It is one of the most important festivals in the country.

feature.name: Victa
feature.origin: Roman goddess of food and nourishment.

feature.name: Vinalia Faculae
feature.origin: Roman wine festivals, celebrated twice a year: on April 23 when the new wine was tasted and August 19 when the new wine was opened for all.

feature.name: Vinotonus
feature.origin: Celtic Briton god of vines.

feature.name: Wangala Tholus
feature.origin: Garo people (Meghalaya and Assam states, NE India, and Bangladesh) post-harvest three-day festival that marks the end of the agricultural year (in November).

feature.name: Xevioso
feature.origin: Fon (Benin/Dahomey) god of thunder and fertility.

feature.name: Xochipilli
feature.origin: Aztec fertility god, associated with maize and flowers; patron of music and dance.

feature.name: Yalode
feature.origin: Dahomey goddess worshipped by women at the harvest rites.

feature.name: Yamor Mons
feature.origin: Ecuadorian corn/maize festival (held in September).

feature.name: [Ysolo Mons]
feature.origin: Albanian festival marking the first day of the eggplant harvest.

feature.name: Zadeni
feature.origin: Ancient Georgian god of bountiful harvest.

feature.name: Zatik
feature.origin: Ancient Armenian god of fertility and vegetation.
